newsitem.title: USA: Florida citrus belt again sees cooler temperatures.
newsitem.headline: Florida citrus belt again sees cooler temperatures.

text.p: Cold temperatures the past two weeks in the Florida citrus belt have been very beneficial to citrus trees to slow down growth rates, the Florida Agricultural Statistics Service (FASS) said.
Temperatures in the low thirties for the week ending December 22 caused no damamge to the crops because of the wind keeping frost from forming, FASS said.
FASS said many caretakers are discing and mowing cover crops, while growers are placing heaters and banking young trees in cold pockets.
Harvest of early and midseason oranges continues to be very active with most going to processors.
FASS reported an estimated 508,000 boxes of Navel oranges were harvested in the week ended December 22, down from 699,000 boxes in the previous week and 691,000 boxes in the week ended December 8.
An estimated 9,614,000 boxes of early and mid oranges were harvested in the week ended December 22, up from 8,347,000 boxes the prior week and 8,364,000 boxes the week ended December 8, FASS said.
